bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Thomas J. Michie, February 27, 1942

div1.p: Hench describes to Michie the role played by Major R.E. Lee Michie in the yellow fever experiments, and suggests that he contact Kean and the War Department for more information.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Thomas J. Michie, February 27, 1942
div1.opener:
Y F.
February 27, 1942
Mr. Thomas J. Michie
Koppers Building
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
My dear Mr. Michie:
div1.p:
I will be glad to send you what information I have on Major Michie.
He only had an indirect connection with Walter Reed. He was the officer in
charge of the soldiers at Pinar del Rio in the summer of 1900 when yellow fever
broke out there. It was not recognized as yellow fever but the doctors stupidly
called it severe malaria. Doctor Agramonte was sent to investigate matters and
found it was indeed yellow fever. The medical officer in charge was Captain
Godfrey. Because of his mistake he was severely censured and some years later
commited suicide. No blame was attached to Major Michie as this was not within
his province. He was considered a very able officer, received continual pro-
motions and I believe in the first world war became a general. That is about
all I know of him.

May I suggest that you write further inquiries to General Jefferson
R. Kean, 2804 No Street N. W., Washington, D. C. He was Walter Reed's closest
friend in Cuba and knew Major Michie well. Ever since he told me about Major
Michie he and I have suspected that he was a relative of the Virginia Michies.
I shall be interested to know if this is true. If this is true and should you
want a formal outline of his military career, I believe you can get this merely
by writing to the War Department and in due time they will send you an abstract
of it. If they are too busy to do this, either one of us could find it without
much trouble the next time we are in Washington by going to the Old Records
Division of the Adjutant General's office in the National Archives Building and
asking to see the personal file on Major Michie. Meanwhile I will look over
the voluminous notes which I have from General Kean and see if I can find any
more for you.

I am sending a carbon copy of this letter to General Kean. He has
not been well the last month but expects to be up and around shortly and I know
will be delighted to correspond with you. Incidentally, Mrs. Kean owns the
house in which Virginia's married sister lives in Washington, just a few doors
from where General and Mrs. Kean live.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:as
